title: Vestibular Migraine and Horizontal Canal BPPV
chief_complaint: I woke up in the middle of the night with severe spinning about 6 weeks ago. Now I get dizzy every time I lie down or turn my head, so I've been sleeping sitting up in a chair.

problem_summary.onset: Sudden onset 6 weeks prior to visit, waking from sleep.
problem_summary.course: Persistent 'bobbing' sensation between episodes; severe spinning provoked by position changes. Symptoms have lasted for days at a time.
problem_summary.laterality: Bilateral tinnitus; vertigo direction unidentified by patient.
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Photophobia, headaches, bilateral tinnitus (1 week duration), otalgia, aural fullness, and anxiety.
problem_summary.functional_impact: Patient has been sleeping upright in a chair for several weeks to avoid vertigo.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Resolution of dizziness to return to normal sleeping and daily activities.

history.present_illness: Patient reported waking with vertigo 6 weeks prior. Diagnosed with bilateral ear infections and prescribed antibiotics by PCP, but symptoms persisted.
history.otologic_history: Otalgia and fullness began 6 weeks prior.
history.medical_psych_history: History of migraines (evaluated by neurologist). Anxiety.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Normal hearing sensitivity bilaterally. Air and bone conduction thresholds within normal limits (0-15 dB HL).

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: Speech Recognition Thresholds (SRT) in good agreement with PTA. Word Recognition Scores (WRS) excellent.

tests.name: Tympanometry
tests.key_findings: Normal ear canal volume, middle ear pressure, and static compliance.

history.present_illness: Continued dizziness, sleeping upright. Photophobia and headaches noted.

tests.name: Videonystagmography (VNG) - Caloric Testing
tests.key_findings: Results indicate a left unilateral weakness, though text describes it as 'equivocal' (21%) while figure caption notes 27%. The clinic cutoff for abnormal is 25%.

tests.name: Dix-Hallpike
tests.key_findings: Right ear down: Unremarkable. Left ear down: Positive for horizontal left-beating nystagmus (no torsional component). Nystagmus did not fatigue on repeat.

tests.name: Positional Testing
tests.key_findings: Geotropic direction-changing positional nystagmus in all positions. Torsional component present in head-left and body-left positions. Strongest nystagmus in head-left position.

history.present_illness: Patient reported headaches improved 90%. Still reported some positional vertigo with improvement since the previous visit.
Patient reported no further positional nystagmus and resolution of headaches.

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient presents with normal hearing sensitivity bilaterally. Vestibular evaluation reveals geotropic direction-changing positional nystagmus, strongest in the head-left position, and horizontal left-beating nystagmus during the left Dix-Hallpike. These findings are consistent with Horizontal Canal Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo (BPPV) affecting the left ear (canalithiasis). The patient also presents with symptoms consistent with vestibular migraine.
counseling_points: Your hearing test is normal, ruling out hearing loss as a component of your condition.
The dizziness you experience when lying down is caused by loose crystals in the horizontal canal of your left inner ear (Horizontal Canal BPPV).
Because the nystagmus beats toward the ground (geotropic) and is stronger on the left, we treat the left side.
We will perform a maneuver called the Lempert Roll (or BBQ Roll) to move the crystals back where they belong.
Your other symptoms (light sensitivity, headaches) suggest you also have Vestibular Migraine, which may require dietary changes or medication managed by your doctor.
notes_for_actor: You are very anxious about lying flat or turning your head because it triggers severe spinning.
You have been sleeping in a recliner or chair for weeks.
Describe a 'bobbing' sensation when you aren't spinning.
Mention that bright lights bother you (photophobia) and you have headaches.
